questions.text: A 45-year-old patient diagnosed with homocystinuria reports joint pain and muscle weakness. Supplementation with which vitamin is beneficial in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Homocystinuria is often due to a deficiency in the enzyme cystathionine β-synthase, which requires Vitamin B6 as a cofactor. Supplementing with Vitamin B6 can help reduce homocysteine levels and alleviate symptoms like joint pain and weakness.

Homocystinuria:


Explanation for other options:

Vitamin B12 (Option B) deficiency causes type 2 homocystinuria, but there will be additional symptoms of neurological manifestation due to lack of adenosyl B12 and accumulation of methylmalonic acid.

Vitamin B1 (Option C) Thiamine deficiency typically presents with symptoms related to the nervous system, such as peripheral neuropathy, cardiovascular abnormalities, and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

Vitamin B7 (Option D) Biotin deficiency causes hair thinning, alopecia, brittle nails prone to splitting or breaking and neurological manifestations since biotin is required for decarboxylases containing enzymes.

Reference:

  • Adenosylcobalamin
  • Methylcobalamin

questions.text: A child presents with anemia, mental retardation, bone pains, and hepatosplenomegaly. Bone marrow biopsy shows a characteristic "crumpled tissue paper" appearance of macrophages. What is the most likely enzyme deficiency in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Gaucher disease, caused by glucocerebrosidase deficiency, leads to accumulation of glucocerebroside in macrophages, giving the classic "crumpled tissue paper" appearance on bone marrow biopsy.

  • Gaucher disease is the most common lysosomal storage disorder, inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.
  • It is caused by deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase (β-glucosidase), leading to accumulation of glucocerebroside in macrophages.
  • Key Features of Gaucher Disease:
    • Hepatosplenomegaly (due to infiltration by Gaucher cells)
    • Pancytopenia or anemia
    • Bone pain, osteopenia, avascular necrosis
    • Neurological involvement in some types (especially Type 2 and Type 3
    • Characteristic Gaucher cells: lipid-laden macrophages with "crumpled tissue paper" cytoplasm in bone marrow biopsy
  • Types of Gaucher Disease:
    • Type 1 (non-neuronopathic): Most common, affects spleen, liver, bone
    • Type 2 (acute neuronopathic): Infantile onset, severe neurological symptoms
    • Type 3 (chronic neuronopathic): Slower neurological progression
  • Treatment:
    • Enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) with recombinant glucocerebrosidase
  • Substrate reduction therapy (SRT) in select cases

Explanation of other options:

Hexosaminidase-A (Option A): Deficiency causes Tay-Sachs disease, characterized by progressive neurodegeneration, cherry-red macula, and no hepatosplenomegaly or "crumpled tissue paper" cells.

Iduronate 2-sulphatase (Option B): Deficiency causes Hunter syndrome (MPS II), a mucopolysaccharidosis presenting with coarse facial features, developmental delay, and hepatosplenomegaly, but not the marrow findings seen in Gaucher disease.

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (Option C): Deficiency causes G6PD deficiency, a hemolytic anemia triggered by oxidative stress (e.g., infections, fava beans), with no bone involvement or Gaucher cells.

questions.text: An infant presents with hypotonia, macroglossia, and hepatomegaly. Additionally, a patient with elevated triglycerides (esterified with long-chain fatty acids) presents with fatigue, and a muscle biopsy reveals fat vacuoles. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Carnitine deficiency manifests with fatigue, and muscle biopsy shows fat vacuoles

Carnitine Deficiency:

  • Common in preterm babies
  • Cause:
    • Inadequate biosynthesis or renal leakage.
    • Hemolysis
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Impaired fatty acid oxidation→hypoglycemia & Lipid accumulation→muscular weakness

Explanation for other options:

Fatty Acid Synthase defect (Option B) causes growth retardation, neurological deficits due to impaired myelination, fatigue or muscle weakness from energy imbalance, impaired wound healing and skin abnormalities due to disrupted lipid synthesis.

Lipoprotein Lipase Deficiency (Option C) causes eruptive xanthomas, lipemia retinalis and recurrent pancreatitis.

Medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency (Option D) causes Hypoketotic hypoglycemia, vomiting, lethargy, irritability, seizures, coma during metabolic crises, hepatomegaly and liver dysfunction due to fatty infiltration and sudden unexplained death.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is found unconscious after playing with shampoo that contained rotenone. Which of the following enzymes is inhibited by this compound?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rotenone inhibits Complex I (NADH dehydrogenase) of the electron transport chain, leading to cellular hypoxia.

Electron Transport Chain:

  • ETC complexes are present in the inner mitochondrial membrane
  • There are 5 protein complexes in ETC: Complex I to V

Inhibitors of the Electron Transport Chain (ETC):

2,4-dinitrophenol (Option D) is an uncoupling agent that disrupts the coupling of electron transport and ATP synthesis in mitochondria. If DNP were added, it would uncouple oxidative phosphorylation from respiration but wouldn't block respiration entirely.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent disorders, exhibit only autosomal recessive inheritance pattern?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cystic fibrosis is inherited in a strictly autosomal recessive pattern. Individuals must inherit two defective copies of the CFTR gene (one from each parent) to express the disease. Carriers, with only one mutated allele, remain asymptomatic.

  • Mutation in CFTR gene that causes formation of thick mucus that blocks airway.
  • CFTR gene encodes protein that regulates transfer of salt and water into and out of cells.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Huntington's disease (Option A):

This condition follows an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern-only one mutated allele is required to cause disease.

Treacher Collins syndrome (Option B):

The inheritance is typically autosomal dominant, though rare autosomal recessive forms exist (<2% of cases). Thus, it is not exclusively recessive.

Achondroplasia (Option D):

This common cause of dwarfism is also inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.

Reference:

Inheritance

questions.text: What could be the possible diagnosis for a patient who presented with tendon xanthomas, a lipid profile showing serum cholesterol = 283 mg/dL and serum LDL = 202 mg/dL, and was subsequently started on lovastatin therapy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of tendon xanthomas and markedly elevated serum cholesterol and LDL levels are classic features of Familial Hypercholesterolemia (Type IIa Hyperlipoproteinemia).

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

  • Tangier's disease (Option B):
    • Caused by mutations in ABCA1 gene→ defective cholesterol efflux → very low HDL.
    • Classic signs include orange-colored tonsils and peripheral neuropathy, not raised LDL or tendon xanthomas.
  • Lipoprotein lipase deficiency (Option C):
    • Defect in lipoprotein lipase (LPL)or its cofactor ApoC-II.
    • Leads to Familial Hyperchylomicronemia (Type I).
    • Presents with severe hypertriglyceridemia, eruptive xanthomas, hepatosplenomegaly, and milky plasma, not high LDL.
  • Familial Hyperchylomicronemia (Option D):
    • Overlaps with LPL deficiency, leading to chylomicron accumulation.
    • Clinical features include eruptive xanthomas, lipemia retinalis, abdominal pain, and pancreatitis.
    • Not associated with high LDL or tendon xanthomas.

questions.text: A patient presents with multiple gastrointestinal polyps and carcinoma, with a strong family history suggestive of hereditary non-polyposis colon carcinoma (HNPCC / Lynch syndrome). Which DNA repair mechanism is defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hereditary Non-Polyposis Colon Cancer (HNPCC), also called Lynch syndrome, is caused by defects in mismatch repair (MMR) genes.
  • MMR normally corrects base-base mismatches and insertion-deletion loops during DNA replication.
  • Mutations in hMSH2 and hMLH1 (located on chromosome 2) are the most common genetic defects in Lynch syndrome.
  • Failure of mismatch repair results in microsatellite instability, increasing the risk of colorectal cancer and extracolonic malignancies (endometrial, ovarian, gastric, urinary tract).

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

  • Nucleotide excision repair (Option B):
    • Removes bulky DNA adducts such as thymine dimers caused by UV light.
    • Defects cause Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP), Cockayne syndrome, and Trichothiodystrophy (TTD).
    • Not linked to hereditary colorectal cancers.
  • Base excision repair (Option C):
    • Fixes small, non-helix-distorting base lesions such as oxidative DNA damage, alkylation, or deamination.
    • Defects associated with MUTYH-associated polyposis (MAP), as well as neurodegenerative diseases (e.g., Alzheimer's, Parkinson's).
    • Not the mechanism in HNPCC.
  • Point mutation (Option D):
    • Refers to a single nucleotide change (e.g., missense, nonsense mutations).
    • While point mutations can cause various cancers, HNPCC is specifically linked to mismatch repair deficiency, not a general point mutation defect

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: In the diagram provided, which enzymes are identified as E1 and E2, responsible for the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl CoA?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The pyruvate dehydrogenase complex orchestrates the irreversible conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA, a pivotal step in cellular respiration. Within this multienzyme assembly, E1 is the pyruvate dehydrogenase that decarboxylates pyruvate, and E2 is the dihydrolipoyl transacetylase that transfers the resultant acetyl group to CoA

Pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) complex:

  • Catalyzes the irreversible conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA in mitochondria.
  • A critical step in aerobic glucose metabolism, as it links glycolysis to the citric acid cycle.
  • Structure:
    • 5 Coenzymes - thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP), lipoic acid, CoA, FAD, and NAD+.
    • 3 products: NADH, CO2, Acetyl-CoA.
    • 3 substrates: Pyruvate, NAD, CoA.
    • 3 subunits: E1 (PDH / PDC), E2 (dihydrolipoyl transacetylase), and E3 (dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase).
  • Irreversible reaction:
    • Pyruvate to acetyl-CoA is highly exergonic and irreversible, preventing direct synthesis of glucose from acetyl-CoA.
  • Regulation:
    • Inhibition: Acetyl-CoA, NADH, and ATP inhibit PDH to conserve glucose.
    • Phosphorylation: Kinase inactivates, and phosphatase activates PDH based on energy status.
    • Hormonal Control: Insulin activates PDH for fat synthesis
    • Calcium: Activates PDH during muscle contraction.
  • Clinical significance:
    • PDH complex deficiencies are rare but serious genetic disorders causing lactic acidosis, neurological issues, and developmental delays.
    • Thiamine deficiency,common in alcoholics, impairs PDH complex activity, leading to pyruvate accumulation and lactic acidosis.

Explanation of incorrect options:

Pyruvate carboxylase and dihydrolipoyl transacetylase (Option B): Pyruvate carboxylase is not part of the PDH complex-it functions in gluconeogenesis, converting pyruvate to oxaloacetate.

Pyruvate dehydrogenase and dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase (Option C): Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase is E3, not E2. Its role is to regenerate the lipoamide cofactor using FAD and NAD⁺.

Pyruvate carboxylase and dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase (Option D): Neither enzyme pair corresponds to the E1/E2 components of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with coarse facial features, organomegaly, corneal opacity, and peripheral neuropathy. A deficiency of the enzyme alpha-L-iduronidase is found. Which of the following is accumulated in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario of coarse facial features, organomegaly, corneal opacity, and peripheral neuropathy, along with a deficiency of alpha-L-iduronidase, describes Hurler syndrome in which dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate accumulate.
  • Proteoglycans are widely distributed in all body tissues, especially in the extracellular matrix (ECM), where they occupy space between cells and interact with structural proteins such as collagen and elastin.
  • These molecules also bind growth factors like TGF-β and adhesive proteins such as fibronectin and laminin, influencing structural organisation and cell behaviour.
  • Their glycosaminoglycan (GAG) chains are polyanionic, attracting cations and water to provide turgor, while their gel-like properties and extended polysaccharide chains act as sieves, restricting large molecules but allowing diffusion of smaller ones, thereby contributing to the large volume of the ECM.
  • GAGs are continuously synthesised and degraded, but their turnover in adult tissues is relatively slow.
  • Their breakdown is carried out by lysosomal hydrolases, including endoglycosidases, exoglycosidases, and sulfatases.
  • When enzyme deficiencies impair this process, mucopolysaccharidoses (MPSs), a group of inherited metabolic disorders, occur.
  • These are typically autosomal recessive and involve the accumulation of GAGs in tissues such as the liver, spleen, bone, skin, and nervous system.
  • Hurler and Hunter syndromes are well-known examples. Hurler syndrome, also known as MPS-I, arises due to alpha-L-iduronidase deficiency,leading to the accumulation of dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate. (Options B, C, and D ruled out)
  • Clinical features include organomegaly, skeletal abnormalities, distinctive facial features, developmental delay, and sensory defects affecting vision, hearing, and the cardiovascular system.
  • Diagnosis may involve urine analysis for GAGs, enzyme assays, and genetic testing, with prenatal diagnosis sometimes possible.
  • The various mucopolysaccharidoses are summarised in the table given below.
  • The term mucolipidosis was introduced for conditions sharing features of mucopolysaccharidoses and sphingolipidoses.
  • In these disorders, such as I-cell diseaseand pseudo-Hurler polydystrophy, defective enzyme trafficking leads to substrate accumulation.
  • Hyaluronidase is a key enzyme that breaks down hyaluronic acid and chondroitin sulfate by cleaving hexosaminidic linkages, generating oligosaccharides that can be further degraded by other enzymes.
  • A genetic defect in hyaluronidase results in MPS IX (Natowicz syndrome), a rare lysosomal storage disease characterised by the accumulation of hyaluronic acid in the joints.

questions.text: Which of the following, if given in large volumes, can lead to hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Among the given options, normal saline, if given in large volumes, can lead to hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis.
  • Large-volume administration of normal saline can result in hyperchloremic non-anion gap metabolic acidosis.
  • This occurs because under normal conditions, chloride and bicarbonate levels rise or fall in opposite directions to preserve electrical balance.
  • Severe acidosis may impair heart function, reduce responsiveness to inotropic agents, alter metabolism, enzyme activity, and coagulation, though some argue it enhances oxygen unloading from haemoglobin and may be preferable to alkalosis.
  • Despite theoretical risks, clinical evidence shows that induced hyperchloremic acidosis has little impact, and it is distinct from lactic or hypovolemic acidosis.
  • The composition of commonly used intravenous fluids is summarised in the table given below.

Explanation of other options:

Dextrose in NS (DNS) (Option A): DNS is not usually given in large volumes and hence unlikely to cause hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis.

5% dextrose in water (Option C): Since 5% dextrose does not contain chloride, it does not lead to hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis.

Ringer's lactate (Option D): Ringer's lactate is associated with the development of metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: A 7-month-old infant presents with developmental delay, seizures, and a cherry-red spot on fundoscopy. The mother has a history of an abortion at 8 weeks. Genetic testing reveals a deficiency of hexosaminidase A. Which of the following accumulates in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the clinical vignette of developmental delay, seizures, and cherry red spot, along with genetic testing revealing hexosaminidase A deficiency, the most likely diagnosis is Tay-Sachs disease, in which GM2 ganglioside accumulates.

  • Sphingolipidoses, a group of inherited lipid storage disorders, result from genetic defects in the breakdown of sphingosine-containing lipids.
  • These conditions share common features:
  • Accumulation of ceramide-containing complex lipids in cells, especially neurons, leads to neurodegeneration and reduced lifespan.
  • Normal synthesis of the stored lipids
  • Enzymatic defects affecting sphingolipid degradation in lysosomes
  • Uniformly reduced enzyme activity across tissues.
  • Effective treatments are limited, though some benefit has been seen with enzyme replacement therapy and bone marrow transplantation in disorders like Gaucher and Fabry disease.
  • Other emerging strategies include substrate reduction therapy, chemical chaperone therapy, and experimental gene therapy.

The various sphingolipidoses are summarised in the table given below.

Explanation of other options:

GM1 ganglioside (Option A): GM1 ganglioside, a derivative of GM3, is clinically important because it serves as the receptor in the human intestine for cholera toxin, enabling the toxin's pathogenic effects.

Galactocerebroside (Option C): Galactocerebroside, also known as galactosylceramide, is accumulated in Krabbe disease, which arises due to a deficiency of β-Galactosidase.

Sphingomyelin (Option D): Sphingomyelin is accumulated in Niemann-Pick disease caused by sphingomyelinase deficiency.

questions.text: A 10-month-old boy presents with recurrent oral lesions and respiratory infections. Laboratory investigations reveal reduced B cell, T cell, and NK cell counts along with reduced adenosine deaminase levels. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis based on the history of recurrent oral lesions and respiratory infections in an infant, along with reduced B cell, T cell, and NK cell counts and adenosine deaminase levels, is suggestive of severe combined immunodeficiency.

Severe combined immunodeficiency is a group of genetically diverse disorders with defects in both humoral and cell-mediated immunity.

Explanation of other options:

Agammaglobulinemia (Option A): Agammaglobulinemia is an X-linked recessive disorder and arises from mutations in the Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK) gene, which disrupts signalling from the pre-B cell receptor, leading to failure of B-cell precursors to mature into functional B cells and causing markedly reduced immunoglobulin levels. Clinically, the disorder manifests after about six months of age with recurrent bacterial respiratory infections, susceptibility to certain viral and protozoal infections, absence of plasma cells, underdeveloped lymphoid tissues, and normal T-cell function.

Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency (Option B): Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by misfolded α₁-antitrypsin protein, most often the PiZ variant, which accumulates in hepatocytes, leading to endoplasmic reticulum stress and impaired inhibition of neutrophil elastase, resulting in lung and liver damage. Clinically, it may manifest in infancy with severe liver disease progressing to cirrhosis, while pulmonary emphysema develops due to unchecked neutrophil elastase activity.

DiGeorge syndrome (Option C): DiGeorge syndrome arises from developmental failure of the thymus due to defects in the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches, most commonly linked to a 22q11 deletion involving the TBX1 gene. This results in deficient T-cell-mediated immunity, hypocalcemic tetany from absent parathyroids, and congenital malformations of the heart and great vessels, often accompanied by abnormal facial features. Clinically, patients show low T-cell counts, reduced resistance to fungal and viral infections, and depletion of T-cell zones in lymphoid organs, while immunoglobulin levels may be normal or reduced depending on the degree of T-cell deficiency.

questions.text: A young boy is brought to the outpatient clinic with complaints of fatigue, muscle cramps, and episodes of low blood sugar after physical activity such as playing. These symptoms resolve with rest. Biochemical analysis reveals reduced serum glucose and lactate levels following exertion. What is the most probable underlying disorder?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

McArdle's Disease, or Glycogen Storage Disease Type V, is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme muscle phosphorylase. This enzyme is essential for glycogen breakdown in muscle cells.

  • Patients with McArdle's disease typically present with exercise intolerance, muscle cramps, and myoglobinuria after strenuous activity.

Explanation for other options:

Hers' Disease or Glycogen Storage Disease Type VI (Option B): It results from a deficiency in liver phosphorylase. While it does cause hepatomegaly and mild hypoglycemia, the symptoms are generally milder.

Cori Disease (Option C): This condition involves a deficiency in the debranching enzyme, leading to mild hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly seen at infancy, limited dextrin accumulation and muscle weakness.

Andersen disease (Option D): This condition involves a deficiency in the Glycogen branching enzyme, leading to hepatosplenomegaly and death before age 5 due to heart or liver failure

Key Points:

Reference:

  1. Glycogen storage disease type III - NIH Genetic Testing Registry (GTR) - NCBI
  2. Anderson-Fabry disease management:
  3. Anderson's Disease

questions.text: DNA packing is done by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

DNA is compacted into the nucleus primarily by histone proteins. These small, basic proteins organize DNA into nucleosomes-the fundamental structural units of chromatin-allowing efficient DNA packaging and playing a central role in the regulation of gene expression.

Histone Function & Structure

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Glycoprotein (Option B): Glycoproteins are proteins with sugar moieties-while they play numerous cellular roles, they do not compact DNA within the nucleus.

Nucleus acid (Option C): DNA itself is a nucleic acid, not the protein that packages it-this answer mislabels the term and doesn't pertain to the packaging mechanism.

Adenine (Option D): Adenine is one of the nucleotide bases in DNA-it has no structural role in DNA packaging.

questions.text: What is the cause of following condition due to?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This disorder is known as Conjunctival xerosis caused by vitamin A deficiency where the conjunctiva becomes dry, rough and irritating

Vitamin A Deficiency - Key Manifestations:

  • Ocular Signs:
    • Leading cause of preventable childhood blindness in developing nations.
  • Early features:
    • Impaired sensitivity to green light.
    • Difficulty adapting to dim light → night blindness.
  • Advanced deficiency:
    • Xerophthalmia: conjunctival and corneal dryness, thickened keratinized epithelium.
    • If untreated → corneal ulceration → opaque scar → blindness.

WHO Grading of Xerophthalmia:

  • XN → Night blindness
  • X1A → Conjunctival xerosis
  • X1B → Bitot spots
  • X2 → Corneal xerosis
  • X3A → Corneal ulcer <1/3 cornea
  • X3B → Corneal ulcer >1/3 cornea
  • XS → Corneal scar
  • XF → Xerophthalmic fundus
  • Bitot's spots: Grayish-white, triangular patches firmly attached to conjunctiva.
  • Keratomalacia: Severe form with corneal softening after prolonged deficiency.
  1. Immune Dysfunction:
    • Deficiency reduces resistance to infections.
    • Infections themselves lower vitamin A (by reducing retinol-binding protein synthesis), worsening immune compromise.
  2. Skin and Epithelial Changes:
    • Follicular hyperkeratosis (Phrynoderma): rough, keratinized skin.
    • Keratinizing metaplasia: atrophy and abnormal keratinization in respiratory, GI, and genitourinary epithelium.
  3. Other General Manifestations:
    • Growth retardation (impaired chondroitin sulfate synthesis).
    • Reduced protein synthesis.

Explanation of other options:

Vitamin C (Option A): Deficiency leads to scurvy, characterized by bleeding gums, bruising, and poor wound healing, not conjunctival xerosis.

Vitamin B (Option C): Refers to a group of vitamins; deficiencies in specific B vitamins can cause various conditions, but not conjunctival xerosis.

Vitamin E (Option D): Deficiency can lead to neurological problems and hemolytic anemia, but not conjunctival xerosis.
